title.narrative: TMT+ Entrepreneurship Education for SS refugees in West Nile Uganda

description.narrative:
Next to each institute’s own wishes and goals, we collaborate on the basis of complementarity. Overall we aim to establish quality TVET in agricultural entrepreneurship that increases the quality of local agriculture, contributes to the food security sector and develops the local private sector in the West Nile region. At the moment, one of the main challenges in the West Nile region is the limited development of a private sector. Only 2% of refugee households have managed to obtain salaried employment due to the lack of businesses and potential employers in the region. This means that a high percentage of people must rely on other sources for livelihood, such as agriculture. By looking more closely into agriculture, the Refugee Response Plan shares that 97% of the host community population and 95% of the refugee population in northern Uganda are engaged in crop production. This means agriculture is the most commonly reported source of livelihoods for both refugees and host communities. However, 75% of households in West Nile report that their land for cultivation is too small to provide food for the entire household. Across refugee-hosting districts, agriculture is characterized by low production and productivity, high vulnerability to climate change and high post-harvest losses. Furthermore, very little value is added to agricultural production through processing and quality, and prices therefore remain low. Acknowledging both the dependency on and insufficiency of food production, it is key to increase agricultural production and productivity.
With this project we align with the CPI description and national policies to move away from humanitarian support for refugees to including students with a refugee background in formal agricultural education together with the host community. TVET can truly be the engine for transformation in the lives of both refugees and host communities. TVET in Uganda (often referred to as BTVET: Business Technical and Vocational Education and Training) can be divided in two categories: formal and non-formal BTVET. Before 2017, a clear distinction between the two categories was made in terms of provider type: formal TVET was offered by formal training institutions (both public and private) and non-formal training was delivered by private companies and NGOs (the total number of informal training centres remain indeterminate, but are estimated at 1000). After 2017 the Ugandan Ministry of Education and Sports drafted their Education Sector Strategic Plan 2017- 20201 to coordinate the education service delivery in the country. One essential change that took place was the development of formal TVET institutes that started offering non-formal training as well, often referred to by the institutes themselves as ‘tailor made training’. This opened up numerous new possibilities for those students who had not reached ‘O’ level in secondary school or dropped out after primary school. It has the possibility to bring positive change for vulnerable youth.
Providing agricultural knowledge and approaches for relief and development programmes while working on the nexus between development and humanitarian aid is one of the embassy’s objectives. This is the shift from humanitarian support for refugees towards empowerment. Uganda governmental policies aim to move away from humanitarian support for refugees to including students with a refugee background in formal agricultural education together with the host community. This will make education for refugees more sustainable. With this project, we support these Ugandan policies by removing barriers on refugee student pathways in TVET education and the shift to self-employment.

The Tailor Made Training plus project targets youth from refugees and host communities in the districts of Moyo, Adjuman, Koboko, Arua and Madi-Okollo. The project will be implemented in TVETs of Adraa as the lead TVET, Koboko, Moyo, Arua and Amelo TVETs. Participating youth will be drawn from refugee settlements and the surrounding communities in the 5 Districts.

The project aims to establish quality TVET in agricultural entrepreneurship that increases the quality of local agriculture, contributes to the food security sector and develops the local private sector in the West Nile region.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Saving Lives Corporate Indicators
Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Thematic Indicators
Number of SMEs with improved business practices

description.narrative: Number of SMEs with improved scores in business operations

title.narrative: Number of communities reached
Sustainable Livelihoods Corporate Indicators
Number of people with increased access to good quantity and quality of food through own production or income

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Number of farmers applying good agricultural practices

description.narrative: Number of farmers that apply Good Agricultural Practices (GAP). GAP activities encompass different components of agricultural practice: dealing with agricultural inputs, handling fertilizers and pesticides use, harvesting practices and personal and product safety and hygiene (when applicable according to EU import regulations)

title.narrative: Number of farmers that have improved access to non-financial services

description.narrative: Number of farmers with improved access to non-financial services (Examples - number with increased access to markets e.g. new market linkages, number with increased access to inputs increase is measured from baseline to Endline)

title.narrative: Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

title.narrative: Number of people supported to improve and/or develop their entrepreneurship prospects

description.narrative: Number of people (within the project's target beneficiary group) supported by Cordaid interventions designed to assist them to develop / improve their entrepreneurship (possibilities)

title.narrative: Number of unemployed youth successfully supported into (self)employment

description.narrative: Number of youth who have secured employment, comparing from before the intervention to after (baseline to Endline). NB Both waged employment and self-employment (i.e. are employed by someone else or have started their own business)

title.narrative: Number of households with more diversified livelihoods (income generation)

description.narrative: Number of households that have been able to diversify their primary livelihood through Cordaid interventions on this field. Diversification here means the process by which rural families construct a diverse portfolio of activities and social support capabilities in order to survive and to improve their standards of living.

title.narrative: Number of (M)SMEs that are investment ready

description.narrative: Number of MSMEs that have both developed business plans and increased their business operations score (measured either by SCOPE Insight or self-assessment questionnaire)

title.narrative: Number of enterprises with improved access to finance

description.narrative: Number of enterprises (farmer enterprises or MSMEs) who have access to finance, comparing before and after our intervention (from baseline to Endline). NB A farmer group = 1 enterprise not 25 farmers. An individual farmer could be 1 enterprise

title.narrative: Number of people reached with employment interventions

description.narrative: Number of people (within the project's target beneficiary group) supported by Cordaid interventions to obtain decent employment A decent employment respects the fundamental rights of the human person as well as the rights of workers in terms of conditions of work safety and remuneration. .. respect for the physical and mental integrity of the worker in the exercise of his/her employment (in accordance finally with the ILO regulations for decent work) .

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (SU)

description.narrative: Number of people who have benefitted (directly or indirectly) through a Cordaid Sustainable Livelihoods Intervention

title.narrative: Education Corporate Indicators
Number of youth attending TVET

description.narrative: Number of youth attending TVET supported by a Cordaid Education intervention

title.narrative: Accountability
% of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.
